text: It is the first time we have seen it. There are about eig girls very busy. Morning confusion. (parts to be written) We pick up essential lines as we PAN DOWN SHOOTING AT THE GIRL'S FACES, assuming the CAMERA to be the board.
Grand Hotel -- good morning -- no,  Baron von Gaigern's room does not  answer... Yes,... all right... Baron  von Gaigern's chauffeur calling.
Good morning, nine-thirty Doctor  Otternschlag... No, Doctor, no  messages... No, Doctor.
Grand Hotel -- good morning... who  is calling Madam Grusinskaya?... Oh,  Mr. Pimenov. Madam Grusinskaya is  not to be disturbed, sir... no, sir...  yes, sir --
The word passes down repeated.
Mr. Preysing's calls to one sixty  two for today.
-- good morning... Mr. Preysing -- (she plugs through)
Telephone bell ringing. General shot. Gerstenkorn, an old business man and Doctor Waitz, counse for the Saxonia organization are sitting at a gree table, smoking and waiting.
(glances at watch) Nine-thirty, Mr. Preysing keeps us  waiting.
(who has returned) He likes to play the great man.
(glancing at market  report from table) The Preysing stock is holding its  own today on the market.
Ask Preysing what it's costing him  to keep it up.
And ask me what it's costing us to  hammer it down.
Exactly.
If the Preysing people get the  Manchester contract, we shall  certainly merge with the Preysing  company -- but if they haven't they're  ruined -- Preysing will have to  declare himself.
Shhh -- here he is now.
The door opens and Flaemmchen enters. She is agreeably  surprised to see the room full of men. She likes men.
(beams) Good morning, gentlemen -- Mr.  Preysing will be here in a minute.
Business of Schweimann and Flaemmchen. Gerstenkorn, making notes, glances at his watch again. Door opens suddenly.
(enters) Good morning, gentlemen.
Good morning.
Sorry I'm late, I've been waiting  for Justice Zinnowitz, my legal  advisor.
Oh -- ho -- you want legal aid against  us? -- The whole thing seems to me  to be very simple.
Very simple -- I've always liked the  way you dressed, Preysing -- English,  isn't it?
(disturbed) What?
(quickly) They turn out marvelous material in  Manchester.
Manchester -- yes. Yes, yes, they  do. Yes -- Now gentlemen shall we  begin at the beginning? -- Have we  cigars -- water and everything?
Flaemmchen, who has been busy preparing her little table work is seen in several CLOSEUPS:
(with a wink to  Gerstenkorn) Manchester is a very interesting  city, don't you think so, Preysing?
(stalling) Manchester -- yes -- yes. A man in  the textile industry naturally has  to know Manchester.
There's a lot of business to be done  with the Manchester Cotton Company.  They've the whole English market  right in their hands. Have you any  connections with -- Manchester?
(quickly) We have a good many connections in  England, naturally.
I mean with the Manchester people?
(looking at Gerstenkorn  impudently) We are here to discuss our merger.  Naturally I can make no statement at  this time. We must begin at the  beginning.
(winking at Schweimann) All right.

(far-away commencing  to read his report) Since, on the eleventh of June, this  year -- when the first negotiations  for a merger between our respective  firms was entered into -- both parties  have fully agreed that this merger  can result only in mutual advantages.
INTERCUT this speech, which if played by Beery will be  interesting, with signals, winks and signs between the ot three men.
Oh -- yes -- I beg your pardon!
I'm laying before you the last general  statement of our concern. Active  capital, plant and machinery, raw  material and finished product -- for  instance -- mop rags --
Mop rags --!
Business between Preysing and Flaemmchen finding papers o 'Mop Rag' report.
What we want to know about is  Manchester.
Yes, Mr. Preysing -- that's what we  want to know.
I'd like to wait for Justice  Zinnowitz, before I commit myself.
Oh -- Preysing, Preysing --
No water -- What a place!
All you have to do is phone for it.
Flaemmchen, who is on her toes and busy every minute, rus to the telephone and gives an order -- her conversation i heard over the conversation of the men in the room -- CAM
Water -- seltzer, three or four  bottles and cigars -- good ones.
I can see this session is going to  be exhaustive.
Now to proceed with the projected  merger, the advantages for the Saxonia  are so obvious...

Oh -- now let's talk like adults.  You want to tell us now a along story  of what your factory can do. We know  all that you could tell us and if  you tell the truth it wouldn't sound  so good. When you first approached  us...
We did not approach you.
(quickly looking  through the papers) Letter on file September fourteenth  would show that you approached...
(snatching the document  from his hand --  losing his temper) It isn't so -- this was a response  to a tentative feeler of your own.
(snatching the document  violently away) Tentative my foot -- a month before  this your old father-in-law came  very privately and scratched at my  door.
Scratched -- (he nearly chokes) We did not take the initiative.
Of course you took the initiative.
Zinnowitz enters the room.
Good morning, gentlemen -- I see the  conference is already underway.
Oh, here you are, Justice Zinnowitz --  I'm at cross-purposes with these  gentlemen -- will you clear up the  situation?
But the situation is perfectly clear,  If you will allow me -- (he clears his throat)
How clear is Manchester?
Foggy -- frightfully foggy, always,  I'm told. (to Preysing) Have you said anything about  Manchester, Mr. Preysing?
I can make no statement about  Manchester at this time.
Well -- gentlemen.
There is dead silence for a moment -- he clears his throa commences in almost the same tone as Preysing.
Since, on the eleventh of June of  this year -- when the first  negotiations for a merger...
(over Zinnowitz's  voice -- with a sigh --  sits back) Thank God we're beginning at the  beginning.
(stops suddenly --  takes glasses from  his nose -- he is  speaking, not reading) As you remember it -- when you  approached us...
(bangs the paper down) We did not approach you.
I know you did -- I said you did --
And I said we didn't.
And I know we didn't.
During all this commotion Flaemmchen is paying no attenti whatsoever. She is calmly spraying herself with a perfume atomizer and smiling at a gentleman. The noise continues  over her.
Sequence omitted from original script.
The atmosphere has changed, the sun shines. Grusinskaya i reclining on the chaise-lounge -- her Chinese robe drawn  about her. She speaks voluably.

Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition  was in my blood -- no rest, no  stopping. We were drilled like little  soldiers -- We danced in the school  of the Imperial Ballet, in St.  Petersburg. I was little and slim  but hard as diamond -- a duty machine --  No rest, no stopping. And then -- I  became famous and whoever is famous  is alone... But why should I be  telling you this? Last night I did  not know you at all -- who are you,  really? -- I do not even know your  name.
I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My  mother called me Flix.
Flix. -- And how do you live? What  kind of a person are you?
I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep  of a white flock -- I shall die on  the gallows.
Really?
Really, I haven't a bit of character.  None at all.
No?
When I was a little boy I was taught  to ride and be a gentleman -- at  school, it was a monastery, I learned  to pray and lie -- and ---
And?
And then, in the war, to kill and  hide. That's all.
And what do you do -- now?
I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large  like a happy pig, devouring anything  of life that pleases me, I really  belong in jail
Oh! What a picture -- and what else?
(seriously) I'm also a criminal and a hotel thief. (he turns away)
That's a silly joke.

(turns -- takes both  her hands) Please look at me. You must believe  me -- you must believe that I love  you -- that I have never known what  love is -- until last night. (he releases her hands  and turns away again.)
What is the matter?
He does not answer.
Flix!
The Baron takes the pearls out of his pocket and lays the before her.
There.
(with a little cry of  pain) Oh -- (in the silence  Grusinskaya puts her  head in her hands  and thinks)
The Baron makes a gesture as if to stroke her hair and th holds back.
(softly) Did you come here just -- just for  that? Oh -- it's horrible.
Pause. She is suddenly cold.
You may keep the pearls -- I don't  want them any more -- I'll make you  a present of them.
(passionately) I don't want them now.
(broken) I'll not denounce you.
I know.
So --
Yesterday I was a thief -- but now, --
But now, you must go... I give you  the pearls. But now you must go ---

I wanted money desperately -- Can  you understand? -- That's why I wanted  the pearls. I was threatened -- I  was desperately in need of a certain  big sum of money. I've been following  you -- I've admired you. But I have  forced myself not to think about you --  Last night, at last, I managed to  came into your room and -- and now.
(softly) And now?
I couldn't go through with it. (his head goes down  into her lap -- he  sighs:) Remarkable.
His hand touches her hair -- tenderly.
Do you understand?
Yes -- yes -- yes.
There is a sudden knock at the door.
Quickly -- here.
With a quick gesture Grusinskaya beckons the Baron to the bathroom. He disappears into the bathroom. She opens the  door, after finding the key and radiantly addresses Suzet
Good morning, Suzette.
(delighted to see her  in a good mood) Good morning, Madam.
She puts the coffee down on the table. Charming piece of business as Suzette, in putting the cof down on the table must necessarily push back the heavily  crested cigarette case of the Baron.
Madam has slept well?
(enthusiastically) Oh, yes, Suzette.
Madam will dress now, it is late.
Five minutes, Suzette, come back in  five minutes. I'll ring.
Yes, madam Suzette knows all about  it.
She is a French woman. She is pleased.
Madam is beautiful this morning.
As Grusinskaya hurries Suzette to the door she says:
Yes, Suzette.
Suzette goes out. Quickly Grusinskaya crosses and flings  open the bathroom door. The Baron comes out.
You must go now.
As she speaks the telephone goes. She gives the telephone dirty look. Telephone rings again. She pulls him across t the telephone.
There -- it begins.
With a hand in his she lifts the telephone receiver and  speaks.
Hello -- hello -- Meierheim? Yes...

During this scene the Baron is touching her shoulder. A  charming light moment. She continues to speak into teleph His touch probably tickles her, she laughs -- quickly cov the receiver so that Meierheim will not hear her laugh.
(to Baron) No --
During this scene she is listening to Meierheim. She frow suddenly --
What?... Cancel Vienna?... Are you  mad? We always have great success in  Vienna... Certainly not. Come here  and see me... yes... good-bye.
She turns to the Baron and their arms go around each othe The telephone rings again.
(quickly) There -- the day begins... I must go  to rehearsal.
She lets the telephone ring.
Grusinskaya --
Yes.
You do believe that I really love  you?
Yes -- If I didn't believe that, I'd  die after last night.
I want to be good to you -- madly  good.
Suzette will be back here in a minute.
I'll go -- good-bye.
Shall I see you again?
Telephone bell rings again.
Suzette will be back here any minute.
When are you leaving Berlin?
Very early in the morning.
For Vienna?
Can't -- can't you -- Couldn't you  come too -- I think it would be better --  for us -- for us both.
Oh -- yes but -- later.
Why later?
I have no money now -- I must get  some first -- I must get some.
I'll give you what you need -- I  have money.
Oh no -- that would spoil everything.  I'll -- I will manage somehow --  I'll manage myself. I will go with  you. When does the train leave?
Six twenty-seven in the morning...  But the money?
Never mind -- I'll get it. I have a  whole day. I'll be on that train.
They move towards the door.

I shall dance and you'll be with me  and then -- listen -- After that you  will come with me to Lake Como, I  have a villa there. The sun will be  shining. I will take a vacation --  six weeks -- eight weeks. We'll be  happy and lazy. And then you will go  with me to South America -- oh!
Telephone starts ringing.
You must go now. Be careful on your  way to your room.
I'll go. -- I love you. (he kisses her) I'll be on that train. I'll get the  money.
She holds him back. The telephone is ringing.
Don't do anything foolish -- I'm  alarmed about you.
Don't worry. I'll be on the train. (he kisses her) He leaves.

Alone with the telephone bell ringing, Grusinskaya breath deeply, stretches herself. She goes to the glass and look at herself -- smiling. Happily she takes the pearls, kiss them, drops them into the casket -- picks up the telephon
(speaking into  telephone) Yes, Pimenov... Yes... where are  you, in your room? Come, I will see  you now... hurry.
She rises from the telephone flutteringly, she is humming tune. She crosses to the mirror, pulls back her hair happ she is indeed younger. Suzette is putting out a dark dress.
Not that dark dress -- something  light -- bright -- it's a sunny  morning, Suzette.
Suzette happily glances at her. There is a knock at the door.
Come in. (sings)
Pimenov enters, before he can speak --
Good morning, Pimenov.
(a little puzzled at  change in her) Good morning, Gru -- your --
Before he can start speaking of last night she quickly sp

Pimenov, I have an idea -- a new  ballet -- it must have mad music --  I'll explain it to you later. But  now, hurry to the theatre -- I want  full rehearsal -- properties -- full  ballet and some musicians. Hurry --  Quickly. I will be there --

During this scene Grusinskaya has not looked at him, she busy in the glass. Nice photography on hair and face. Side scene between Suzette and Pimenov, as Suzette shows the cigarette case on the table. As he goes through the door Grusinskaya crosses and almos sweeps Suzette to the door with him.
Gru -- you are positively radiant.
Yes, Pimenov. (quickly to Suzette) One minute, Suzette, I will call  you.
They leave. Grusinskaya shuts the door. She sweeps happily to the  telephone.
(very very softly -  her voice is like  music to operator) Hello -- will you -- will you get me  Baron von Gaigern, please... yes...  Baron von Gaigern -- yes...
While she waits, she moves with a sense of dance.

(again into telephone) Will you get me Baron von Gaigern,  please... (she speaks quietly) Cherie... yes... it is you...  nothing... good morning, good morning,  cherie... nothing... no... just to  tell you I'm happy.
Bring music up.
Music effect over sign "Grand Hotel." Precisely the same  angle as before. The sign lights.

The music comes up on the DISSOLVE into the original key  shot of the lobby. Senf is busy. The Baron's chauffeur is standing impatiently by his desk Business ad lib of Senf. He turns to the chauffeur who is barring the way of an important looking alien.
Step back please.
Chauffeur makes no effort to move. Against the normal bus happy traffic of the evening he is a sinister figure. He  does not move but glares at Senf.
I've told you three times -- Baron  von Gaigern is out.
Did he leave any message for me?
No, he did not -- there is no message.
This whole scene is played in a very low key, almost in a whisper, it is interrupted by the entrance of the Doctor.
(to Senf) Any letters?
No, doctor.
During this short scene the chauffeur saunters off. Kringelein comes to the doctor.
Oh, Doctor, such a day -- such a  day!

They move away from the scene. Kringelein's voice diminishes as the CAMERA MOVES followi the chauffeur. The chauffeur saunters unthoughtfully past the florist sh and out of the door. As we pass the florist shop we see t back of the Baron in the shot. CAMERA PANS chauffeur out to door. He has not seen the Ba in the florist shop. THE CAMERA PANS back to florist shop waits for the Baron who emerges carrying his usual box of orchids. CAMERA FOLLOWS BARON back to Senf's desk. Key sh
(to Senf) Madam Grusinskaya.
(taking the flowers  and handing them to  clerk) For Madam Grusinskaya.
(to page boy) Madam Grusinskaya -- at once --
(to Baron) Your chauffeur's been waiting, Baron.
(Quickly -- shortly) All right. (he glances around  apprehensively)
Kringelein is speaking to the doctor. The Baron approaches them.
Baron, we must have gone a hundred  miles an hour, at least...
Yes, quite.
(to doctor) We've been together all day... and  in an aeroplane.
Life is changing you, Mr. Kringelein.

Yes, thanks to the Baron. The best  shops, the very best. Look, Doctor,  silk -- feels so nice on the skin...  a London hat, see -- made in England,  that's silk, too -- fifty marks...  Look, the price is on it. That was  half my salary before. The Baron is  a very fine gentleman -- no one in  my life has been so nice to me as  the Baron.
The Baron smiles. He slaps his gauntlets on his dusty coa
I'm going to change and we'll meet  for a drink in the Yellow Room.
In the Yellow Room, where the music's  playing and the ladies are?
(amused) Where the music's playing and the  ladies are...
The Baron leaves.
No pain, Mr. Kringelein?
Pain? Oh, no, Doctor. I think if I  had pain I'd be too happy to notice  it...
NOTE: Find cut here. While Kringelein is talking, they move away from the CAME
The Baron enters, throws his gloves down on the bed, turn up the light, picks up a piece of paper that's been pushe under the door, glances at it.
In scrawl: "I HAVE BEEN WAITING ALL DAY. WILL BE OUTSIDE
We again see the apprehension on the Baron's face. He cro closes the window. As he does so we hear the noise from t conference room. Bring up noise from the conference room.

We must have the feeling that these men have been arguing all day. Cognac bottles, cigar ends, selzer water, remain of some sandwiches. In other words it is a business  battlefield. Preysing is drawn and tired. Zinnowitz is on his feet. Flaemmchen is fast asleep in her chair, making pretty picture.

...and let me say again for the tenth  time... (he is hoarse and  tired) ...you people were quite ready for  the merger. You declared yourselves...  fully agreed on all the terms -- Why  should the signing of these articles  be suddenly held up?
I've admitted that at one time we  had reason for desiring ther merger --  What reason have we now? The Preysing  Company has fallon upon evil days,  very evil days.
Preysing jumps to his feet.
Evil days -- I've shown you here -- (he bangs the paper) -- my company exports to the Balkans  alone, sixty-five thousand marks  worth of mop rags a year.
Mop rags -- mop rags -- we're  interested in something quite  different!
What?
(to Gerstenkorn --  with a sigh) Shall I tell them again?
(glancing at his watch) Why waste time -- it's getting late.
You see -- what we are interested in --
(interrupting) Ah, come on -- we're going home.
Due to the long tedious session the men's collars are wil
(rising) Mr. Preysing has too scrupulous a  regard for certainties...
You've talked enough today, you're  hoarse now.
His hand goes to his pocket. Slowly he takes out the tele and glances at it. The following scene is played over thi closeup.
Sorry, Preysing. (he gets his hat)
(nervously) You've decided against the merger?
Yes --
Then, it's all over?
Yes --
(to Zinnowitz) Well -- well -- You could call my  office.
There is a general movement to go.
Trembling in Preysing's hand. "DEAL WITH MANCHESTER DEFIN
Gerstenkorn crosses to Preysing.
Goodbye, Preysing, I hope you pull  through. This is a very bad time to  be in such a crisis. We've...

(interrupting) Why talk -- it's over -- it's over --  it's finished. You've broken off  negotiations. You did it. You're  calling them off. You had nothing on  your mind all day, but Manchester, --  Manchester -- Manchester. (he develops almost a  passion) You don't suppose for one moment  that I'm such a fool as not to have  something that I could say definitely  about Manchester. (he is generating  almost a passion)
What?
Oh no -- no -- the session is over.  Let's go, it's off. Thank you,  gentlemen. (he starts packing up  his papers.)
If you actually have news from  Manchester then...
Gentlemen, I am now free to  announce... (he is perspiring,  his hands are  trembling) ...that the deal between my firm and  the Manchester Cotton Company has  been successfully negotiated.
Preysing, you're joking with us.
You're a deep one.
In that case give us the articles.  We'll sign at once. We know all the  details...
(smiling, slowly folds  up the telegram and  puts it back in his  pocket) I thought we'd suspended negotiations,  gentlemen.
Under these circumstances it's quite  a different matter.
Under these circumstances we might  refuse to sign.
By this time, Waitz and Zinnowitz have the articles out u the table. Preysing is perspiring. Gerstenkorn puts his arms around Preysing's shoulders.
Come on -- business is business --  Come on --
Preysing stands, looking ahead of him. Gerstenkorn picks up the papers glances at them, looks at Waitz. Flaemmchen is awakening.
Here's my signature -- here Preysing,  sign here.
What a session this has been.
While Preysing is signing.
It's twenty-five to six.
We should celebrate this with a bottle  of wine.
(with his hat and  coat) See you soon, Preysing. Next week  we'll meet and discuss further  details.
Next week.
Hasty hand-shaking, business of exits. Waitz, Gerstenkorn and Schweimann out. Preysing has not moved. Zinnowitz takes the agreement and waves it in the air to the signature.
(to himself) Next week.
You let me talk till I'm hoarse and  you had Manchester sewed-up all the  time. Why?
Preysing does not answer. Zinnowitz amiably shrugs his shoulders.
Well -- the deal has been put through.
Preysing commences to laugh suddenly with increasing viol
Yes, it has been put through -- it  has been put through.

During this scene, Flaemmchen has risen, piled up her pap glanced at her watch. During this action Flaemmchen motio to Zinnowitz that she is going down to dance, etc., Preys is unaware of this action. Flaemmchen leaves the room try not to attract attention.
(to Preysing) What's the matter with you?
(hysterically) Bluff -- Bluff -- all bluff.
What's bluff?
(throwing the telegram  on the table) That.
(reading at out loud) 'Deal with Manchester definitely  off! "Preysing, oh -- I'd never have  thought it of you.
No one would have thought it of me.  I've been getting rusty in  Fredersdorf. Well, if bluff is what  the world wants I guess I can put up  as big a bluff as anyone. From now  on... (he turns away)
You must go to Manchester at once  yourself and really see it through.
Yes -- I must go to England -- I was  desperate -- Now I don't care --  This sort of thing goes to a man's  head.
What you need is some relaxation.
Yes -- that's what I want -- I'd  like to tear loose -- I'd like a  drink. I'd like to go down to that  dancing place. I'd like to start  something.
I can understand that -- after your --  uh --
Say it -- say it -- my lie -- it's  the first time in thirty years that  I've ever... Where's that  stenographer? Miss Flaemm...
What do you want with her?
I want to see her, I want to do some  dictating -- report of the conference  for my father-in-law.
She had an engagement in the Yellow  Room at five o'clock -- she was in a  hurry.
Zinnowitz, would you say she was  pretty?
Pretty as a picture.
Let's go down and find her -- I need  a drink -- Come along Zinnowitz. (he is picking up  papers) I don't know anything about women --  been married for twenty-six years.
Bluff does it, Preysing, bluff does  it. Goodnight.
Preysing is very excited, they start to leave -- at that  moment the telephone rings.
Aeh!
He crosses to the telephone.
(into telephone) Hello... Father-in-law?... Is that  you?... The agreement is signed -- I  did it... yes, father-in-law... but  now I must go to Manchester.
When he picks the telephone up his hands are shaking --
-- which shakes more. Music crashes up --
Kringelein and the Doctor are just entering. Kringelein i changed. His hair has been cut short and his moustache is gone, he looks almost saucy.
(to barman) Barman -- whiskey -- (to Kringelein) For you, Mr. Kringelein?
For me? -- Oh, please, something  sweet and cold.
A Louisiana flip, sir?
A Louisiana flip, that sounds very  nice -- sweet, eh? --
During the following speech Kringelein keeps reaching for the moustache that is not there. He is thoroughly happy.

What do you do in the Grand Hotel?  Eat -- sleep -- loaf around -- do  business -- flirt a little -- dance  a little. A hundred doors to one  hall and nobody knows anything about  the person next to him. When you  leave another takes your room and  lies in your bed -- the end.
At that moment Flaemmchen enters.
Good evening, Mr. Kringelein --  Where's the Baron?
I'm waiting for him here. The Baron  and I have been together all day. A  hundred miles an hour -- in a motor  car -- and in an aeroplane -- It was  marvelous --
Mr. Kringelein -- How you have  changed, you look so nice.
Oh, thank you, Miss Flaemm. Oh,  please, Miss Flaemm -- Permit me,  Miss Flaemm, won't you have something  sweet -- a Louisiana flip. (to barman) A Louisiana flip.
(to barman) No - absinthe.
(amazed) Yes -- that --
Kringelein is beating time to the music -- a little carri away. Flaemmchen laughs.
You like music?
Yes -- it's stimulating -- a man  might --
(mischievously) A man might what?
I don't know -- I'd like to do  anything --
(very quietly) Oh -- you would!
The Baron enters quickly.
(to Flaemmchen) Hello -- sorry I'm late.
Oh -- here you are, Baron. A drink --  A Louisiana flip?
Hello, Mr. Kringelein. How do you  feel now?
A little strange, Baron.
I'd given you up.
(to Flaemmchen) Sorry.
A drink, Baron -- A Louisiana flip?
No thanks -- keeping my head clear.
Dance then? (they exit)
(to Doctor) She's beautiful -- isn't she?
(to Kringelein) Oh -- there are plenty of women.
What have you been doing all day?
Chasing around.
Chasing what?
Money.
They dance a few steps, in silence.
You were very different yesterday.
Yesterday -- yes -- that was  yesterday.
They dance into the crowd.
Well, Mr. Kringelein, are you getting  what you're looking for?
What, Doctor?
A masculine paradise -- drink, the  ladies, dancing...
I had a very good opportunity, a  young lady asked me to dance -- I  ought to be able to dance, it seems  to be very important.
You must learn as quickly as your  time allows -- Believe me Mr.  Kringelein, a man who isn't with a  woman is a dead man.
Haven't you anyone -- Haven't you  anybody -- you -- I mean -- Are you  all alone in the world.
(quietly) I'm always alone -- I have been  everything.
Everything?

I was sent as a military surgeon to  South Africa. Stinking climate. Taken  prisoner. Home on parole not to fight.  I was a surgeon in the Great War  till the end. Grenade in the face.  Carried diphtheria bacilli in the  wound until 1920. Isolated two years. (pause) I've been everything.
The music has stopped.

head_text.subj: BARON AND FLAEMMCHEN ON DANCE FLOOR

text: That was lovely.
Will you do me a big favor?
I'll do anything for you.
Would you like to make a man happy?
(quietly) Yes -- I'd love to.
Then dance the next number with  Kringelein.
Why?
I feel sorry for him.
You're not a bit like you were  yesterday.
I fell in love last night -- the  real thing.
Oh -- there's no real thing -- it  doesn't exist.
I thought that, too -- but I found  that it does. Come along, dance with  Kringelein.
Anything for you.
They move off. As they approach the bar, happily Preysing pushes into scene, touches Flaemmchen's arm.
Miss Flaemm.
Hello!
I must speak with you, Miss Flaemm.
(with the Baron) Presently, Mr. Preysing.
It's urgent.
Pardon me, the lady has urgent  business here with me.
(to himself) Insolent -- Berlin manners.
At that moment Kringelein has descended from the stool an crosses to Preysing.
I wish you a very good evening, Mr.  Preysing. You are staying here, too,  Mr. Preysing?
I don't know you.
Oh -- you must know me -- Kringelein  at the plant. Assistant bookkeeper,  building C, room twenty-three --  third floor.
(quickly) Come and dance with me, Mr.  Kringelein.
I must speak to you, Miss Flaemm --  business.
(lightly) Tomorrow morning.
No -- now.
Do you gentlemen know each other,  Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Preysing --  Baron von Gaigern.
They bow stiffly.
Mr. Kringelein will be a good friend  and not accept your invitation to  dance.
I could not think of not accepting.

You say that you are employed by us  in Fredersdorf, and here you are in  Berlin, indulging in diversions which  ill befit your position and which  are very much beyond your means --  Quite extraordinary, Mr. Kringelein,  I think we will look into your books.
Kringelein stands watching Preysing, his eyes narrowing.
Now, children, no fighting -- save  that for the office. Let's have our  dance. (her arms go around  Kringelein. They  dance off)
I'll remember you, Mr. Kringelein.
Oh, let the poor devil alone.
I did not ask your advice.
The two men eye each other; for a moment there might be a fight.
I think it would be much better if  you went away.
We shall see who remains here the  longer.
(shrugging his  shoulders) As you will.
Preysing leans against the bar, orders a cognac. The Baro turns his back to him, watching the dancing.
You must look at my face and not at  the floor.
Yes.
You're trembling.
I never danced before -- in public.
You dance splendidly.
I'm happy, Miss Flaemm.
Really?
For the first time in my life, I'm  happy.
Kringelein shows signs of exhaustion. Flaemmchen watches him quickly.
Let's stop -- I'm tired.
It is obvious that she has stopped because of Kringelein' distress.
Thank you, Miss Flaemm.
They move back to the bar. Preysing catches Flaemmchen's  arm.
Well now, Miss Flaemm, we can talk.
Some champagne, Miss Flaemm?
You may go, Mr. Kringelein.
Does the world belong to you, Mr.  Preysing?
What is this insolence?
Do you think you have free license  to be insulting? Believe me you have  not. You think you're superior, but  you're quite an ordinary man.
Go away -- go away.
Please -- please!
You don't like to see me enjoying  myself.
Who are you? -- An embezzler most  likely.

An embezzler -- you're going to take  that back, right here in the presence  of this young lady -- who do you  think you're talking to? You think  I'm dirt, if I'm dirt, you're a lot  dirtier, Mr. Industrial Magnate  Preysing.
You're discharged.
Me?
Yes you -- shut your mouth -- get  out -- you're discharged.
Kringelein's hat has fallen from the stool upon the floor Flaemmchen picks it up, brushes it. Kringelein starts to laugh. The Baron steps into the scene. The Doctor slowly comes from the bar.

You can't discharge me -- I'm my own  master now -- at last. I'm ill, I'm  going to die -- do you understand?  I'm going to die very soon. Nothing  can happen to me now. Nobody can do  anything any more to me. By the time  you can have discharged me I shall  have been dead already. (his laugh becomes a  convulsive sob)
The Baron steps between the two looking straight into  Preysing's face.
Come, Mr. Kringelein. (he pulls him out of  the scene towards  the bar)
(his fists clenched,  between his teeth) The man's insane -- he acts as if he  is glad he is going to die... (hesitates -- to  Flaemmchen) I shall see you in the lobby in half  an hour.
General activity. The house detective, later identified, is talking to the  chauffeur. He leaves the chauffeur and crosses to Senf.
Better let him stay -- I've sent for  the Baron... How's your wife coming  along?
I was at the hospital all night  walking up and down the corridor.  They wouldn't let me in to see her.  She has the pains, but the child  doesn't come and I have to stay here  chained to this desk.
It will be all right.
I hope so.
At that moment Preysing enters.
Did you send that page?
The young lady's there, sir.
Preysing glances off to see Flaemmchen standing looking  around. Preysing crosses to Flaemmchen.
Oh, yes, Mr. Preysing?
Sit here. (calls to a boy) Cognac -- for you?
Nothing.
At that moment the Baron and Kringelein pass. Preysing glances up at Kringelein as he passes.
I'm going to keep an eye on that  Kringelein fellow. I'll find out  where he gets the money to hang around  the Grand Hotel.
Well -- you want me?
(looks straight at  her) Yes.
Well?
I must go to England -- at once.
Well?

You see, I'd like to take a secretary  with me for my correspondence and -- humm -- humm -- for company on the  trip -- I'm nervous -- I need somebody --  I don't know if you quite understand  me. You said you have travelled with  gentlemen -- and I mean --
I understand perfectly.
What do you think your salary would  be -- for such a trip?
Wait -- I must figure it up. (she smokes and thinks) First, I'll need -- clothes -- shoes --  it's cold in England in March, I'll  need a suit... You'd want me to look  nice?
Of course -- of course. (he is fidgeting)
A thousand marks -- (she waits anxiously  thinking it might be  too much)
It's agreed -- I will get a room  here for you.
She is looking away.
I can get a room here in the Grand  Hotel for you.
She still looks away.
Can you pay some attention to me?
Oh, yes.
(looking off) Insolent young cub!
You mean Baron von Gaigern?
Baron!
Well, he's a gentleman!
Who is leaning against a chair by a pillar with Kringelei THE CAMERA APPROACHES THEM. They are not speaking. The Baron is looking off at:
Sauntering between the door and Senf's desk.
He slumps on the arm of the chair.
(watching him) The Baron is tired?
No, Kringelein, not tired, -- just -- (he shrugs his  shoulders) Well -- well --
Perhaps this evening, Baron, we could  go to the Casino -- the place we  passed with the marvelous bright  lights?
I'd like to Kringelein, but I can't --  I am broke!
Broke -- A Baron? But, Baron --
The Baron looks off, sees the chauffeur --
Arguing with Senf.
Excuse me, Mr. Kringelein. (he strides off)
Keep the CAMERA on Kringelein as he watches the Baron. He takes out his pocket-book and looks at his money comme to count it. The thought is in his mind of offering the B money. Charming scene.
Moving into position. They are talking.
(quietly) I've quit.
You can't.
I'm not going to get those pearls  and neither are you.
What about the money?
I'll pay you back.
How?
I have an idea working in my head... (he glances at  Kringelein)
You might find a bullet through that  head...
If you did that, you'd get nothing  except the police after you. If you  wait -- I'll give you your six  thousand back --
At that moment a voice is heard.
Madam Grusinskaya's car -- Madam  Grusinskaya's car.
It is passed along.
(calls through his  little telephone) Madam Grusinskaya's car --
(outside) Madam Grusinskaya's car --
(quickly to chauffeur) Later. (Chauffeur exits with  bad grace.)
Baron looks off...

Like a pageant Grusinskaya sweeps forward -- pretty shot. Music comes up. Grusinskaya is followed by Suzette, Pimenov and Meierheim People turn to look at her. She sweeps forward. As she gets to the door she faces the Baron. She steps qu aside to him. Pimenov and Meierheim pause.
(to them) Go on please -- go on, Suzette.
She and the Baron are alone.
(quietly) Bless you...
Are you coming to the theatre? Oh --  I shall dance tonight -- How I shall  dance -- I want to feel that you are  in the theatre.
I can't.
No?
No! I can't explain now. Oh, look --  the pearls. You wear them now...
Why do you think --
Why?
They've brought me such good luck --  you --
He takes her hand, kisses it quietly.
I'm worried about you.
Don't.
On the train?
Yes -- I will be on the train.
Till then.
Bless you --
During this scene Kringelein has been hovering nearby. As Grusinskaya turns away and exits, Kringelein approaches t Baron, who is standing perfectly still, looking off, -- h mind miles away.
Was the Baron joking, or is it really  true that the Baron is -- in financial  straits.
(lightly) Absolutely true, Kringelein and I  have to raise some money immediately.
If the Baron -- if you would permit  me --
The Baron looks at him suddenly.
What?
I would be awfully glad to oblige,  you've been so decent to me. Three  hundred?
If I could get into a game I might  win some.
Gambling! I'd like that. I have over  six thousand eight hundred marks  with me.
If we could scare up some men to  play.
We could come to my room.
(with enthusiasm) Good!
At that moment Flaemmchen passes.
Going?
Yes --

Flaemmchen hesitates as though she wanted to say somethin that is on her mind. A curious little scene. She doesn't speak, she just turns suddenly through the do The Baron glances after her a little puzzled, turns back Kringelein.
Ready, Kringelein?
Ready, Baron.
They move off and are last in the crowd.
No scenes 88-93 inclusive Sequence omitted from original script.

Possibly ten men are gathered about a green table. They a playing cards. There are champagne bottles, glasses, etc. on the table -- a great deal of smoke. Good atmosphere. T game is [...] fer. There is a dead silence except for the monotonous words of the players. White faced, the Baron has the bank. Otternschlag is seen to close the door quietly and approa the table. Kringelein's back is to us. They are smart people, not professional gamblers. There is a tension in the room. The men are gathered arou tightly. We do not see the cards. The following voices are heard:
All right, gentlemen.
I play -- I play -- Here -- Up --  Playing --
Yes -- me.
Several men glance at Kringelein and the size of his stak
Is that too much, Baron?
(glances down at his  own money) No -- not at all.
All right then.
All right then.
There is tension in the room. The Baron deals two cards.  Kringelein takes cards.
(quickly) Don't show them.
Kringelein turns it down. He is like a little boy learnin new game. The Baron deals himself a card.
(to Baron) What do I do now?
The Baron is serious. There is enough money on the table take him to Vienna.
(next to Kringelein) Turn 'em up.
Oh yes -- that's right -- look! I  win, don't I -- (he turns the card up)
The Baron rises.
There you are gentlemen.
(to Kringelein) Will you take the bank, sir?

Yes -- I'll take everything gentlemen --  please, let us drink -- champagne --- champagne is expensive and good. I'm  winning more than I used to earn in  a year -- double what I used to earn. (he is counting his  money)
They hand him the cards. Kringelein kisses the Baron -- he looks around.
Where is the Baron -- where are you,  Baron?
At the side table the Baron is standing -- he is drinking his face is white -- he has lost.
(rising quickly) Excuse me, gentlemen.
(sitting down in  Kringelein's place) I'll take the bank -- All right,  gentlemen.
Kringelein has come to the Baron.
That was my last.
You've lost everything?
I've no luck.
Pardon me, Baron. Permit me again... (he puts bills in  Baron's hand.)
Baron pours out a glass of champagne -- he has been drink plenty -- he hands glass to Kringelein.
Drink to me, Kringelein -- it's my  last chance.
(earnestly) I do drink, Baron -- I drink to you,  Baron and to win. (he drinks) It's good, -- come along, Baron.
They both move back to the table where the Doctor holds t bank.
I take five hundred.
All of that at once, Baron?
The Baron picks cards, shows them to Kringelein who doesn understand.
Eight. (he is triumphant.)
(rings in background) Nine.
The Baron throws the cards into the middle of the table a turns to Kringelein:
That's it. The luck's with you. (he walks away.)
Come along, Mr. Kringelein. Sit here.
I'm having luck for the first time  in my life.
Your bank, Mr. Kringelein.
Kringelein seats himself, puts his glass of champagne dow on the table. Doctor leaves table, crosses to Baron who is pouring anot drink.
Out, Baron?
(bitterly) For a while -- I'll recover -- in  ten or twenty years. (he points) Look at that.
He has pointed and turned off because we hear Kringelein' voice:
I've won again, Baron -- I've won  again.
Baron moves out of scene followed by Doctor. As Baron  approaches table.

Baron, I drink and win -- I drink  and win -- I win and drink! (he is pulling money  towards him, counting  it, eagerly,  frantically, not the  movement of a miser,  not a greedy movement,  but the movement of  an excited child  liberated. Money has  become so much mad  paper to him.)
During the foregoing scene, one of the men at the table h answered the ringing of the telephone bell, he comes back now.
There are complaints in the hotel  about the noise.

What time is it? Getting late? Let's  break it up! (to Kringelein) You've been very lucky... Where's my  coat? Let's go. He's drunk anyway!...  Goodnight, Baron. Let's wind up the  game, I'm broke and tired; you can't  play against him. I put my hat down  here, somewhere. I think I'll have a  drink before I go. By the way, I've  got to see you tomorrow morning.  How've you been, Doctor?

Business ad lib. General business of slow normal exit. Kringelein looks up from counting his money. He has been  like a little boy with a Christmas stocking. He looks up  suddenly, sees men are leaving --
Oh, don't go, gentlemen! -- Stay a  while. (he stands to his  feet) Be my guests!
By this time the men are pausing by the door.

I oughtn't to presume, but I -- (he is a little drunk) I'm so grateful to you -- it's been  so marvelous. The first time in my  life I have gambled -- I've danced!  Oh, you can laugh, gentlemen, but  it's the first time in my life I've  ever tasted life!
(slapping him on back) Splendid!

There is a general feeling in the room that although this man is drunk he is terribly sincere, and that there is no wish to embarrass themselves or him. In fact, there is a  nervous impatient movement among the men. But Kringelein reached an emotional pitch.

Life, gentlemen, is wonderful, but  very dangerous. You must have courage  for it, then it's wonderful. You  gentlemen don't know that because  you are all healthy and happy, but I --  believe me -- a man must know death  and not until then does a man know  anything about life.
(sings) Rejoice in life while yet the small  lamp burns.

General noise among men, some are ribald, others are seri Two men come and shake hands with Kringelein, bidding him goodnight. The Baron puts his hand restrainingly on Kringelein's  shoulder. Kringelein almost staggers towards the sideboard. The men are nearing the door.
(starts singing) It's a short life and a gay one...

(seizing a glass of  champagne) Every glass high to life -- the  splendid, dangerous, mighty, brief -- brief life -- and the courage to  live it. (turns to Baron) Baron, you know -- I've only lived  since last night -- but that little  while seems longer than all the time  before -- all the -- (he collapses suddenly  onto the floor)
Business ad lib. The doctor is there quickly. The Baron next.
Drunk.
Poor fellow.
General normal business ad lib between the men. Perhaps t of them help him up, including the Baron. They carry  Kringelein to the bed.
(of players mingling) Drunk? No, he's ill. Looks ill. (well paused over:) He's a doctor -- The doctor's here --  He's just drunk!
Gentlemen, this man is ill -- very  ill -- if you will leave.
Certainly, Doctor. Goodnight!  Goodnight, Baron! Bad luck!
He's not used to champagne -- why  does he drink it?
Little comedy on exit. Ad lib. INTERCUT FOR RELIEF -- Kringelein's face -- white, drawn, tragic. One man, perhaps, remains.
Can I help, doctor?
No, the Baron will stay.
Certainly.

Man leaves. During this scene the Baron has been carefull making Kringelein comfortable on the bed, bolstering pill behind his head. Kringelein's eyes are shut tightly, his  hands are limp. By the business of the Baron, although we do not of cours know it, this is the time that he takes the wallet from  Kringelein and puts it in his own pocket. We might perhaps remember a sudden turn away in which we his back and his right hand raised as though reaching in inside pocket -- He stands looking down at Kringelein.
(drops Kringelein's  hand) It will be over in a minute.
Kringelein's eyes flutter. His voice sounds hoarsely:
Over -- over so soon -- it has just  begun. (he closes his eyes  suddenly) Oh, the pain.
Try and sleep, Kringelein, don't be  afraid.
(mutteringly) I'd like to live a little longer but --  I'm not afraid to die -- I'm not...
(touching his shoulder  gently) You'll be all right, Kringelein. (he moves from the  bed -- takes out a  cigarette, moves to  the table. He seizes  his drink)
(out of scene) My pocketbook... my money in it...
What do you say -- what?
We watch Baron's face, he looks back over his shoulder.
You what -- Oh, isn't it there?
No -- But no I -- Baron, I've lost  my pocketbook.
Baron turns in this scene. He walks forward toward them. The Doctor's hands are on Kringelein's coat.
There is no pocketbook here... On  the floor probably. (He glances down)
(starting up suddenly) More than fourteen thousand marks...  were in that pocketbook.
(looking at Baron) Fourteen thousand marks... One can  travel -- one's happiness might depend  on fourteen thousand marks -- don't  you think so, Baron?
(with a shrug) Quite possibly.
At that moment, Kringelein, who has been staring up at th ceiling, his hands clenching and reclenching, starts up.
Oh, I've got to find it.
Stay where you are.
No -- I must find it -- (he starts talking) Fourteen thousand two hundred marks. (he pulls himself to  the side of the bed)
The doctor goes to restrain him.
I'm all right, Doctor. There's no  pain now -- only you don't know what  that money means to a man like me.

He is suddenly on his hands and knees, crawling along the floor, looking for it, like a little boy; his drunkenness his condition, makes the situation tragic. He actually ge under the card table. The Doctor looks at the Baron. The Baron only watches Kringelein. He follows him, fascin

(talking at intervals  as he crawls looking  for money) You don't know, because you've never  lived like a dog -- in a hole -- and  saved and scrimped. My life hangs  upon that money, Baron. Nobody gives  you anything. You have to buy  everything and pay cash for it. I  wanted to pay for my last days with  that money. Every hour costs money.  I've nothing -- nothing but that  pocketbook. (he crawls along the  floor on his hands  and knees talking to  the carpet as he  looks) I must have it back. (he pauses breathless --  like an animal along  the wall -- looking  up at the men)

The foregoing speech is intercut with the following actio in which Kringelein's voice is heard throughout -- thus i is not a long speech: The Baron watches. He throws his cigarette away -- he bit his lip -- sweat breaks out upon his forehead; again he i thief. When he wanted pearls the love of a woman stopped  him. Now he wants this money and pity, a slow growing pit for this tragic, dying thing is stopping him -- and all t time the Doctor watches. The one, whole eye pierces into the Baron's melting  conscience. Twice during the speech at a spot, through and during  rehearsal, to be selected, the Doctor's voice, droning bu piercing, says:
He must find his money, Baron. (next time) Mr. Kringelein should find his  pocketbook, Baron, shouldn't he?

These are two interjections. And now, Kringelein lies upon the floor, a troubled littl sack of pain, his head down. The Baron turns away. He bends down as though he were loo for the pocketbook. We see him take it from his pocket an turn. There is a very light, almost triumphant ring in hi voice as he says:
Here -- here it is. Here's your  pocketbook, Kringelein.
(his head coming up) Oh -- yes -- that's it -- you found  it -- you found it for me, Baron.
(quickly) Goodnight, Kringelein. (he moves towards the  door.)
No -- no please -- oh, don't go --  don't go -- don't leave me alone,  Baron.
You've nothing to fear, Kringelein
No.
Come, get up -- come let me help  you.
NOTE: If he is a strong actor he can pick Kringelein up - If not, he and Doctor lift Kringelein to bed.
You're all right now -- it's very  late -- goodnight, Kringelein.
Oh, no, stay here, Baron -- stay.
Baron bites his lip. It is the first and only time in the play that we see a tear near -- the strong man almost bre
Goodnight, Baron.
Goodnight. (his hand presses on  Kringelein's shoulder --  he exits)

Baron shuts door and pauses. In front of him is the door the woman he loves. Down beyond is his own empty room. In his pockets nothing. In his CLOSEUP he makes the audience feel his problem with him. This man who has lived and whistled and love through the  play becomes a tragic, lonely, harrassed figure. The Baro has broken. His fists dig into his eyes -- he brushes his hair back. Over this comes with almost an impertinence, a tiny whist He looks up and away down the corridor. The figure of  Flaemmchen stands there, a small black bag in her hand. T Baron pulls himself together and smiles characteristicall He walks down the corridor.
Flaemmchen, what are you doing here  in the middle of the night.
Looking for my room -- one sixty- six.
You live here?
For tonight. (she points to door --  she looks at him a  long time)
Oh!
Yes -- oh!
Well -- such is life, Flaemmchen.
And Baron, thanks so much for  everything.

They both go into their respective rooms. Here are our two gay young characters. The gay, fresh  Flaemmchen and the debonair Baron, crucified for lack of  funds. Both trying to smile, both trying to be light abou themselves. Yet, each about to involve themselves tragica for the want of a little money.

Flaemmchen enters her room cautiously. Except for one lam burning the room is in darkness and empty. From the adjoi door to Preysing's room a thin stream of light. She puts  down her bag quickly, tiptoes through the bathroom to his door. She peeps through.

from her angle. Preysing stretched on bed flat, his stomach a mountain an on it the magazine that he has been reading with Flaemmch picture. He is looking at the ceiling. She knows he is aw because a thin stream of smoke comes from his cigar in hi hand.

An idea occurs to her. She could possibly sneak into bed he would go to sleep and there would be nothing that nigh CAMERA FOLLOWS HER as she tiptoes to her room. She closes the door noiselessly and listens. She throws off her hat takes off her coat. Opens her bag and takes out night dre lingerie, etc. The lid of her bag falls suddenly. She sta at the noise. "Has it awakened him." She looks off.

The thin stream of light is filled suddenly, the door of adjoining room opens and back-lighted from the other room the huge form of Preysing appears. In this odd lighting h is a little more than Preysing. He comes forward. He spea hoarsely, quietly.
Flaemmchen! (he seizes her to him)
She goes to his arms passively. He rubs his face in her h She is passive -- cold.
(breathlessly) You are late. I've been waiting for  you -- waiting.
I had to arrange about the trip.
You're sweet.
You think so?
He holds her again, trying to kiss her. She deliberately  avoids his kiss.
(awkwardly) Come here. (he sits heavily on  the bed, sitting on  her night dress.)
Here, hold up!
Preysing rises while she pulls her night dress from under him. He draws her to him.
Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.
Call me -- do you know -- would you --  would you like to call me by my first  name?
(pulling away, glad  of an excuse for  conversation) Oh, no.
Why not?
I couldn't do that, you're a stranger  to me.
You're a funny little creature,  Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.

It's not funny at all. One can't get  intimate just off hand. I could go  to England with you and everything  like that -- supposing I met you  next year and I said: 'How do you  do, Mr. Preysing! And you said: (she imitates him) 'That was the young lady who was my  secretary in Manchester'.
Preysing laughs. She laughs.

That's all quite proper. (she is happy again.  She would rather  talk than be squeezed) But supposing I met you when you  were with your wife and I called  out: "Hello you big baby -- remember  Manchester?' And you with your wife,  how would you like that?
There is a pause for a moment.
Please, Flaemmchen -- we'll leave my  wife out of this.
Flaemmchen yawns straight in his face.
All right. I'll get undressed -- get  out.

He moves towards the windows which are open. She pushes h fat body out, almost playfully, through the doors and ont the balcony. Preysing stands out on the balcony. He looks down in the  street below, then off. He starts suddenly because he see shadow over the railing of his own balcony. He is puzzled Shadow crosses again. "Who can be in his room?" He moves  forward and peeps through the window. One side of the Fre window is closed. From his angle we see the Baron furtive searching the room. He is now wearing an overcoat, the co is turned up. Business ad lib. He finds Preysing's wallet He stuffs this in his overcoat pocket. Preysing's face  watching him. As Baron turns to exit, Preysing surges for pulling the window after him. The two men face each other
Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want  here?
I must have made a mistake.
Made a mistake -- remarkable. We  shall soon see if you made a mistake. (the Baron starts to  leave.) (bellowing) Stay here... Give me that money.
The Baron hands him the pocketbook without a word.
So that's how we stand, Baron.
Look here, sir -- I'm completely at  your mercy -- I'm desperate -- it's  a matter of life or death -- I had  to get some money -- tonight.
Indeed you must, Baron -- you must.  Humm -- humm, but you must go to  jail, Baron, you're a thief.
Be quiet.
I'm going to call the police. I'm  going to watch you play the great  Baron with the police. Aristocrat!  Aristocrat! (he picks up the  telephone)
The Baron makes for the door on the other side of the roo pulls at the knob.
The door is locked, Baron.

The Baron makes one dive across the room. Preysing grasps his coat and tears it. With one hand holding the telephon (the receiver dropping on its cord towards the ground) an one hand holding the Baron.
(into telephone) Hello! Hello! --
Don't do that. (he tries to snatch  the telephone from  Preysing.)
Preysing wrenches the telephone suddenly away from the Ba The action excites him.
Strike me, would you? Attack me would  you? Attack me --
With a terrific lunge, Preysing brings the telephone down upon the Baron's head. The Baron sways, stunned. (as in b In his mad rage, Preysing, hits again with the telephone.
I'll strike you -- I'll strike you --  I'll strike you -- Strike me!
By this time the Baron is a heap on the floor. We see Pre come out of his blind trance. He even repeats again.
I strike you -- (with telephone  foolishly in his  hand, he looks down  at what he has done.)
Sharp sound of buzzing. Dozing night girl plugs in, lazily.
Yes -- yes -- Operator -- Operator -- (she listens -- says  to herself) They are having a nice little game  up there with the telephone.
With nonchalance she flicks plug out again, as she does s

New angle. Preysing is on his feet. He has replaced the  receiver on the telephone, he is putting it back slowly. is terrified. Door opens behind him. Flaemmchen, with a dressing gown on, light, filmy thing,  crosses and looks down at the Baron, without a word. Prey seizes her. Her hand goes to her head, her eyes roll; for a moment we think she is going to faint right on top of the Baron. Sh is trying to collect her senses, it cannot be true. We ca hear nothing but the heavy breathing of Preysing and the  traffic below. Suddenly a motor horn in the street below sounds strident it is the first time we have been conscious of it. With a swift movement, Flaemmchen dashes towards the door It is locked. She rushes back as if to cut through her ow room. He reaches for her and rips her dressing gown from  her, leaving her almost naked. He lunges after her. She t through her own room.

Flaemmchen enters from her room. She looks this way and t After all, it is Flaemmchen and not Lillian Gish, running across the ice in "Way Down East," -- it is Flaemmchen, a Berlin girl. She pauses to try and clear her brain. "What the hell is this -- what is it." The impulse naturally is scream in alarm. She doesn't -- Flaemmchen's don't. She l around. At the end of the passage is Kringelein's room. S will go there. We watch her run down the passage uncertai Without knocking she pushes open Kringelein's door.

It is in darkness. The only light comes through the windo The form of Kringelein lies prone upon the bed, the Docto had just thrown a coat over him. He is still in his trous and shirt. Like a ghost, Flaemmchen, the shreds of her filmy clothes hanging to her, crosses.
(hoarse whisper) Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Kringelein --  where are you?
She sweeps to bed. She shakes him. Kringelein starts up.
Quick -- Mr. Kringelein.
Oh -- what -- what -- (he is looking up at  what seems to be a  ghost.)
She pulls on the light by the bed, it flames up on their  faces.
Oh -- oh, Miss Flaemmchen. It's you --
Quick -- something awful -- awful  has happened. Go -- go at once, --  Mr. Preysing --
Preysing?
It occurs to him that this girl with her torn clothes mus have been roughly treated by Preysing. He suddenly assume strength.
Oh, don't wait -- go -- it's awful --  it's awful.
She slides down to the floor, by the side of the bed. Kringelein climbs out of bed, tries to help her up.
Stay here.
She waves him away.
Don't wait now -- go -- Preysing.

Kringelein assumes suddenly a strength. He is a man for a crisis -- he forgets that he was ever ill -- he leaves. WE GO WITH HIM. CUT HIM DOWN CORRIDOR QUICKLY. He pauses  outside Preysing's door, uncertain of the rooms, then he  knocks.
(calling) Mr. Preysing -- Oh, Mr. Preysing --
He feels there must be a mistake -- he steps back, sees  Flaemmchen's door open next to it. He enters.
He enters. Looks around. Looks through bathroom. Goes qui forward.

Preysing is still leaning against the table, his mouth is open, he is gaping -- stunned. The two hundred and four p has collapsed and sagged. He is staring, his victim lying a heap upon the floor, very still and quiet. His eyes com around as Kringelein enters. Kringelein crosses, looks down. Touches the Baron's hand.
Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.
He tried to rob me -- he is dead --
My best friend -- poor, Baron --  dead -- just like that.
-- We must do something...
(quickly) Yes, the police must be called.
No -- no -- wait -- the man was a  burglar -- he was going to steal my  money.
Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.
(suddenly) Where is that girl -- she was working  with him -- she enticed me into her  room.
Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing --  I understand, Mr. General Director  Preysing.
(frantically) I can answer for this, it was self- defense -- I can answer for this --  but that girl -- the scandal -- my  wife -- my daughters, you know them?
Yes, I know them --

The scandal -- we are men -- you --  you could take that affair of the  young lady upon yourself -- take her  and hold your tongue. Then you can  travel -- I'll give you anything --  anything -- she was with you.
We must call the police, your  excellency.
Preysing takes him by the shoulders.
How much -- how much do you want --  you need money -- you have nothing.
Don't worry about me, Mr. General  Director Pryesing -- worry about  yourself. (he picks up receiver) There has been a murder -- this is  room one sixty-four.
Telephone girl plugs in.
Hello -- hurry up... hurry up...  someone in one sixty-four says there  has been a murder.
The scene gradually grows intense. Porter calls night man
Here - quick - here -- go to one  sixty-four immediately. (calls back on  telephone) Give me Mr. Rohna -- Rohna the  manager.
Darkened room. Bell ringing. Rohna sits up in bed, turns light, picks up telephone; on his face we see him hear th news.

Where?... murder?... who?... all  right, I'm coming. Wait a minute. (speaks in a monotone) Instruct everyone to use the utmost  tact -- we must have no scandal in  the Grand Hotel. Answer no questions,  I'm coming now -- inform the police.
(he replaces the telephone commences dressing quickly)
Trunks standing around everywhere. Suzette is finishing  packing. Grusinskaya is sitting in front of the mirror in loose night wrap -- she is doing her hair.
Madam should sleep.
I've done my hair differently -- do  you like that?
When a lady falls in love she does  her hair differently.

(rising) In the middle of the night -- those  flowers make me think of a funeral.  Laurels and tube-roses. (she pushes the window  closed, shivers, it  is chilly. She crosses  the room turning out  one of the lights) Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and  the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple --  happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.
(quietly) Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep.  It is not long 'till the train.
Goodnight, Suzette.
Suzette leaves -- turning out a light. Alone, Grusinskaya goes to the telephone. She raises the  receiver.

Hello -- can you tell me if Baron  von Gaigern is in his room -- ring  him. (talking to herself) Cherie, I must wake you or you'll  miss the train. (into phone) ...yes... are you ringing, he may be  asleep. (to herself) Cherie, you must get up and fetch me  from my room -- I'm longing for you,  Cherie -- I have not been to sleep --  I kept thinking you would come to  me. (into phone) ...Oh, but he must answer. Ring --  ring -- ring.
CUT IN HERE at discretion the:
Telephone is ringing.

(to herself) Cherie, hurry -- hurry -- hurry.  Answer the phone -- what is the  matter. (into phone) Ring him -- ring him. (to herself) Where are you -- where are you,  Cherie? Why don't you answer? (into phone) Well, ring him -- please -- please.
Music up as we --
The trees and the milk cart effect and other curious sign of dawn, which we remember after the climax of the first  sequence. Music cold and eerie.

General early morning bustle and activity. From one van, fruit and vegetables are being unloaded. Fr another, huge hind quarters of beef are being carried in in a monotonous way a baker throws two loaves at a time, another man, from a van backed up --
(counting) Forty-two -- forty-four -- forty-six --  forty-eight -- fifty -- fifty-two --

Waiters coming to work. A noisy racket. Sandwiched between the bread and butcher vans, is backed hearse. At the moment we come upon it, the men are pausing in the work to glance. The men take off their caps, as; proceede by the hotel detective and others, who will be there, the corpse of the Baron in the basket, used at such time, is  brought out and placed in the hearse, which drives noisil away. A policeman rides with the driver on the box. By this time the man with the bread is counting:
One hundred and eight -- one hundred  and ten -- one hundred and twelve...
Stay with him for a moment.
Shooting onto door - day lighting. A man comes out and signals a black closed limousine, whi pulls forward.

Early morning. Sense of chill and desolation. Some chairs stand on tables. A vacuum cleaner is at work on the carpe Newspaper boys are delivering papers at the news stand. T various shops are slowly being opened, the windows being  cleaned. The general feeling of the beginning of another day. THE CAMERA waits at a distance shooting from door as Prey with a plain clothes man on either side of him, leaves, m towards THE CAMERA. He is grim, his hat is drawn over his eyes. His hands deep in his pockets. When he has passed t

(the old shot) Meierheim is entering quickly goes through the door. He crosses now to Pimenov. They talk eagerly out of earsh But it is apparent that Meierheim is, as usual, in a hurr Rohna is there too. One of the men carries a telephone st wrapped loosely in paper. But we know it's the telephone  stand. Senf comes on duty, looks around, it is apparent that he late.
The night clerk has already gone --  you are late.
Man -- I was at the clinic the whole  night -- there are no words to  describe what my wife suffered.
And the child isn't coming?
No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't  let it interfere with my duty. Any  news here?
News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.
What? -- Who? -- Whom?
The big manufacturer killed Baron  von Gaigern.
Good heavens. What for?
I don't know.
Man -- that's terrible. He was a  nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.
It seems that he was a thief and an  imposter.

I don't believe it -- he was a real  gentleman. I know people... I'm so  tired I can hardly see out of my  eyes. No sleep for two nights and so  many duties and now this killing in  the hotel -- that means a lot of  work. But it's too bad about the  Baron, you always felt better when  he came along -- always friendly --  such an agreeable fellow.
Most imposters are --
A number of bellboys march up and form a line. Senf comes from behind the desk and inspects them.
Good morning.
(in chorus) Good morning.
Show your hands.
They show their hands.

(to one boy) You have dirty nails -- you little  pig -- you're no good... Caps off! --  Let's see your hair. (Boys take off their  caps) Good -- caps on! (Boys put on their  caps) Where is number seven?... Not here? (to clerk) Take his name -- if he comes late  again today, he's fired. Dismissed!
The boys sit down on the bench. THE CAMERA MOVES TO KRINGELEIN. Kringelein and the police officer move towards the desk i ear shot.
Please, officer.
That will be sufficient for the  present, sir, you may travel in peace.
Kringelein exits.
As Kringelein emerges from the elevator, Suzette speaking the Floor Clerk.
And they've taken him away.
Yes -- it's terrible.
Madam must not know -- you understand --  Madam must not know.
I will tell the maids. I cannot answer  for downstairs --
Suzette hurries down corridor. By this time Kringelein ha arrived at his door, he opens it.
Kringelein opens the door and enters. Flaemmchen is looki into space. A lovely picture. Morning light over her hair she is dressed.
What's the matter?
Oh -- I was thinking -- Poor Baron --  Lying there, his eyes so open.
You loved the Baron, didn't you?
Yes --
So did I. He was friendly to me as  no man ever was.
Perhaps he really was a burglar --  But they don't kill a man for that.
He was in desperate straits. He'd  been trying to raise money all day.  He laughed -- Poor devil! And then a  man like Preysing kills him.
(naively) I didn't like Preysing right off.
Then why did you have anything to do  with him?
(simply) Money!
Yes, of course, -- money!
You don't understand that do you?

Of course I do -- I never knew what  money really meant till I started  spending it. Do you know -- (he is silent a moment) I can hardly believe that anything  so beautiful should come to me from  Preysing -- I'll take care of you.  Will -- will you let me?
What?

You'll have a good time with me.  Want to? I've got enough money. Ten  thousand two hundred in my pocketbook.  Three thousand four hundred that I  won. It will last a long time. I can  win more -- we'll travel.
Yes -- to Paris? I wanted to go there  always.
Wherever you like. Here I'll give  you the money I won, three thousand  four hundred. Later you can have  more.
Later?
When I -- I'm ill, Flaemmchen -- It  will not be long -- I'll not last  long. Will you stay with me until...
Nonsense! We'll find a great doctor,  he'll cure you. They can cure anything  these days.
Do you believe that you will have a  better time with me than you would  with Preysing?
Oh yes, of course.
(takes her hands) Do you like me better?
You're a good man, Mr. Kringelein --  a very good man.
Kringelein straightens, happy, inspired, a smile on his f He assumes in his gestures. Takes the telephone.

(into telephone) When is the next train leaving for  Paris? -- Yes... Get two tickets for  me... and my bill please... and the  lady's -- Miss Flaemm's. (puts down telephone) (to Flaemmchen) We have to hurry let's pack -- we'll  have breakfast on the train.
The figure of Grusinskaya is standing at her door, there no one with her. Suzette steps out.
Madam, it is Mr. Meierheim -- he is  waiting downstairs.
Where is Pimenov? Where is Pimenov? (she looks off.)
coming out of the elevator. Grusinskaya hurries down to Pimenov -- they meet.
(breathlessly) He will be on the train.
But when did he go? How do you know?
She crosses and looks in the Baron's room. A maid is ther changing the bedding. The room is unoccupied otherwise.
Baron von Gaigern has left?
The maid nods.
When? How long ago?
Maid shrugs her shoulders.
The Baron left about half an hour  ago, Madam.
Oh -- Gru -- come, come -- we'll  lose the train.
While they are waiting for the elevator Grusinskaya is li a live electric wire. The elevator arrives. They are stepping in.
General activity. We hear the cry go up:
Madam Grusinskaya's car...
Grusinskaya comes out of the elevator followed by Suzette and Pimenov. Meierheim meets her.
Come along, oh, Madam, come along.  The train will be going.
Wait a minute. I've got to ask myself.
What's the use of asking, Gru -- he  is at the train -- He will be there.
The troupe, the scenery, everything --  all on board, waiting. You have a  rehearsal in Vienna tomorrow morning.  Come, Madam, are you mad?
Grusinskaya crosses to the desk. She speaks to Senf.
Have you seen Baron von Gaigern?
(comes over quickly) The Baron is not here, Madam.
He is gone?
Yes, Madam.
Four minutes past. Please come.
Come, Lisaveta, he will be there --  he will be there.
(calling) Madam Grusinskaya's car.
Grusinskaya, followed by the others, sweeps out towards t door.
Grusinskaya emerges, followed by the others. The sunlight hits them.
Oh, the sun -- it will be sunny in  Tremezzo --
Every seat for the opening has been  sold at Vienna. Sold out for three  days.
I know -- I know -- but it will be  sunny in Tremezzo. We'll have a guest  then.
(knowingly) Yes, Madam.
Madam Grusinskaya's car.
Grusinskaya moves forward.

(at telephone) Grand Hotel, Head Porter. What?  There's been -- a child born? A boy!  Yes! My child born! It is healthy...  and my wife? Doing well -- all well! (to Clerk) The child has come. They are both  alive. My child...

At this moment Kringelein and Flaemmchen are coming out o the elevator, Kringelein is carrying his suitcase. A bellboy attempts to take his bag but Kringelein, still  confused draws his hand with the suitcase away from the  bellboy.
Let him take it.
Your bag, your Excellency --
Hearing the word 'Excellency' Kringelein goes through a  transformation. He stands and with a flourish hands the  suitcase over to the boy. He is a big man now.
(very definitely to  boy) Cab please!
Cab, for his Excellency, Mr.  Kringelein!
(to Flaemmchen) And now we travel, Flaemmchen...  Glad?
Am I!
(to Senf) Is the bill ready -- the lady's too?
At once. Any forwarding address, Mr.  Kringelein?
Yes, Paris -- Grand Hotel.
How do you know there is a Grand  Hotel?
Oh, there must be one in Paris...  They have everything in Paris.
Your bill, Your Excellency.

Kringelein pays and taking Flaemmchen's arm starts to mov away from the desk, General business ad lib of tipping. B line up, making a deep bow. There is almost a triumphant  march as Kringelein and Flaemmchen move towards the door.
(in chorus) Come again, your Excellency.
With head erect, happy smile on his face, Kringelein leav the lobby. Normal activity in lobby, reminding us of open scene. Doctor comes up to desk.
Was that Mr. Kringelein leaving?
